docs.lead_paragraph: There were tears in Joe Girardi's eyes, and he did not try to wipe them away. His brown eyes were red because he was talking about losing his mother, losing his baby and finally, hopefully, having a new baby. The emotions were unusually close to the surface. As Girardi discussed what he, his wife, Kim, and his family have endured -- and what they expect to eventually enjoy -- he spoke softly and evenly. He believes in hope. God, he said, has a plan for everyone, and life's travails will somehow be handled. At least that is what Girardi wants to believe. Sometimes, it has been complicated.

headline.main: Throughout Life's Many Travails, the Yankees' Girardi Is Keeping the Faith

docs.abstract: Article on New York Yankees' player Joe Girardi and his wife, Kim, focuses on their closeness and deep religious faith as they face life's travails, including Kim's miscarriage 10 weeks into her pregnancy in April 1997; Girardi comments on being a father, now that Kim is three months pregnant; photo (M)
docs.snippet: There were tears in Joe Girardi's eyes, and he did not try to wipe them away. His brown eyes were red because he was talking about losing his mother, losing his baby and finally, hopefully, having a new baby. The emotions were unusually close to the...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''There are two schools of thought on maternity clothes,'' said Katherine Betts, the fashion news director of Vogue, who is expecting a baby in June. ''The one that says you should wear a tent and hide. Or the French school, which says you should show off your pregnancy. Pregnant Frenchwomen are incredibly chic.'' For pregnant Americans, Liz Lange Maternity opened a store this month upstairs at 1020 Lexington Avenue (73d Street). Ms. Lange, a former Vogue editor, has sold her body-hugging line from a showroom to luminaries like Elle Macpherson, Cindy Crawford and Elisabeth Shue. Ms. Lange said her clothes are ''skintight, but they'll stretch to fit from conception to delivery.'' Now, less famous women with equally great expectations may buy her tiny T-shirts ($85) and low-rider bootleg pants ($175), which button under the stomach. ''Women don't realize that they look smaller if they're wearing smaller clothes,'' Ms. Betts said, but cautioned that ''you can't be the self-conscious type.'' ELLEN TIEN
docs.abstract: Stretchy, body-hugging maternity clothes are available at new Liz Lange Maternity store on Upper East Side, Manhattan; photo (Pulse column) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN Paris one summer, my husband, Michael, and I were sitting on the sunny steps of the plaza outside the Musee d'Orsay, having just spent hours glutting ourselves on the Impressionist paintings. Like our fellow footsore tourists, we were thumbing through newly purchased postcards and art books. Suddenly, a van pulled up, the rear doors opened and two skinny youths in T-shirts pushed an upright piano onto the pavement. The pianist produced a stool, plopped himself down and began to play a riff, while his companion assembled a clarinet. Soon, the squiggles and syncopations of jazz and honky-tonk entertained a delighted audience who rewarded them with a large pile of francs. We have a phrase -- ''the mind's eye'' -- for remembered sights, but no such expression exists for sound. Whenever Michael and I travel, we dutifully preserve the views in photographs, which we eventually plaster into albums. But it's the musical experiences, both planned and serendipitous, that often evoke the most pleasurable memories: the nostalgic notes of the odd oboes and brass playing the sardana in front of Barcelona's cathedral; the mellow tones of the artful flutist in a Roman metro passageway; the robust oompahs of a band in the Strasbourg town square; the icy tremolos of Vivaldi's ''Winter'' played by a chamber orchestra in the church of St.-Julien-le-Pauvre in Paris.
docs.abstract: Barbara Comins article on memories of music heard while traveling; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a beautiful, springlike day in early December, and as Ruth Lippin sat in an examination room at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, waiting for her very interesting brain to be scanned in the adjoining neuroimaging suite, she gazed out the window and took in what was once for her a bloodcurdling scene: the Hudson River, the Jersey Palisades drenched in sun and, looming in the middle distance like a nightmare hammered together out of rivet and steel, the George Washington Bridge. There was a time not too long ago, the 39-year-old Lippin said cheerfully, when the mere thought of crossing that bridge in an automobile filled her with extreme dread, a physiological immersion in fear most of us can only imagine. ''Somehow I figured out how to get the phone number of the 24-hour control booth for the bridge,'' she said, still dismayed by the depth of her anxiety and embarrassed about the ingenuity it inspired. Lippin -- a mother of two, a lawyer and now a Manhattan therapist who treats people with phobias -- recalled the lengths to which she used to go to avoid getting stuck in traffic on the bridge. ''I would call them, and I'd say, 'I know this sounds crazy, but I'm in a car and I'm anxious about crossing the bridge in traffic and want to know if it's clear or not.' And if it wasn't, then I wouldn't go over.''
docs.abstract: Stephen S Hall article on fear, what is known about how it works, how it can be treated, and what is says about our unconscious; fear expresses itself in an array of disorders, including panic attacks, post-traumatic stress disorder, phobias, obsessive-compulsive disorder and generalized anxiety, which, taken together, affect more than 23 million Americans; in explosion of new research, every aspect of fear is being scrutinized by neuroscientists and psychiatrists; studies suggest that experience of irrational fear and anxiety represents an anatomical battle between conscious 'autobiographical' memory and unconconsious emotional memory waged and stored in different areas of the brain; drawings (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: After 20 years as a unifying force on the New Jersey Supreme Court, Justice Stewart G. Pollock announced today that he would resign in September, giving Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yet another opportunity to appoint a member to the state's highest court. Justice Pollock, whose skill at consensus building and quiet diplomacy led several fellow justices to refer to him as ''the Rudder,'' is known as a constitutional scholar who was instrumental in building majority decisions that supported abortion rights, upheld the constitutionality of the death penalty and realigned the way New Jersey finances its public schools.

headline.main: Judge Leaving High Court After 20 Years as Unifier

docs.abstract: New Jersey Supreme Court Justice Stewart G Pollock, afer 20 years as unifying force on court, announces that he will resign in September, giving Gov Christine Todd Whitman yet another opportunity to appoint member to state's highest court; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A family history of schizophrenia increases the risk that a person will develop the illness, but environmental influences like place and season of birth are also significant risk factors, according to the findings of a large epidemiological study by Danish researchers. The study, published in today's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, found that having a parent or a sibling with schizophrenia increased a person's chances of developing the illness by about sevenfold to ninefold. But people who are born in the winter months, in particular in February or March, or who are born in urban areas, are also slightly more likely to develop schizophrenia than people born at other times of the year or in rural regions.

headline.main: Study Shows Role of Time and Place of Birth in Schizophrenia

docs.abstract: Large study by Danish researchers finds family history of schizophrenia increases risk that person will develop illness; finds being born in winter months, particularly in Feb or Mar, and being born in urban area slightly increases risk; findings add weight to theory that viral infection in pregnancy may be risk factor; New England Journal of Medicine publishes study (M)
